body.creator: Olivia Flores
body.value:
As Barry leaves his office, his normally clumsy walk turns into dance moves, as if he feels a new spring in his step thanks to Lena and the harmonium. Alternatively, his movements left and right might be seen as a boxer's steps.

At the beginning of the film, he says that he's "still on hold," and here, he says, "I don't know." Punch-Drunk Love, then, documents Barry's process of understanding what he wants and how he can achieve love with Lena. He begins as a hero who lies constantly—to others and to himself—and who struggles to give voice to his desires. By the end of the film, however, he will be brutally honest with Lena and will be clear about what he wants.

body.creator: Olivia Flores
body.value: The map on Barry’s office wall is divided into regions, likely related to his business operations, with, no surprise, blue and red marker—once more an echo of Barry’s and Lena’s color palette. The latter separates the (wild) west from the placid Plains and Midwest. The question is, will blue and red be able to merge by the end of the film?

body.creator: Olivia Flores
body.value: On a literal level, this dollar represents the first money Barry's business made. On a more symbolic level, it signifies early on the film's persistent fascination with money, commodities, and transactional relationships. Indeed, all levels of the plot—from the phone sex line to the pudding scheme—are tied to monetary exchanges.
